You should see around my Chilean lantern tree after the common whitetail garden bees here(Ireland) tear the flowers apart,  a literal carpet of red mulch.   As the plant has no natural pollinators in this location, the plants usually do not go to seed,  but many of the flowers now produce seed from the bees' ravaging.

When I saw them tunneling into my house, I used OFF! spray on entrances to their tunnels to get them to abandon their tunnels and leave. They would come back, but by then I would have my taser racket ready to knock them down and kill them. If anyone needs to get rid of them, use this technique.

when humans consume parts of plants or animals or fungi or even bacteria, we call it "eating," and when these animals do what they evolved to do and exploit sources of sustenance we call it stealing. it may sound like a semantic observation but the way we talk about things informs how we think about things and by describing the practices of one group of animals as "theft" a moral component is implied and it can result in villainization of certain classes of organisms, e.g. so-called "parasites" (just read the youtube comments on videos relating to cuckoos and you'll see what i mean). the audience for popular science such as what you do here is by definition not an expert audience and if you aren't careful with your language it can reverberate through culture in unpredictable ways and there are always consequences
